Dear Paris Marie Miller:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/4/2025, 9/5/2025, 9/12/2025 and 10/02/2025 . Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-g Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (g) If the employee has criminal
convictions, the institution shall complete
a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction,
the length of time since the conviction,

and the relationship of the conviction to
regulated activity for the purpose of
determining suitability for employment in
the institution.
Three of eighteen new employee files reviewed failed to document the completion
of a written evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the relationship of the
conviction to regulated activity when the employee had documented criminal
convictions.

• The agency was provided consultation regarding staffing ratios and the
utilization of additional Havenwyck Hospital staff assisting in this role.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2024 Interim Audit: Corrective Action Plan was approved on 2/13/25 and
addressed the violations found during the Interim inspection completed on
01/20/2025. The report contained the following violations: The agency was found
to be in non-compliance with R 400.4109 Program statement due to the agency
not following their established staff to youth ratio. The agency policy indicates
that the staff to youth ratio is 8:1 and on 11/06/2024 the agency staffing was not
in compliance with this policy; R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
requirements; staff qualifications Four of nine employee files reviewed failed to
document completion of a criminal history clearance as required prior to the start
of employment; R 400.4132 Grievance procedures Two of three files reviewed
failed to document that the grievance policy was provided to residents and
families at the time of admission; R 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions

or shelter care institutions; initial treatment plan One of three reports reviewed did
not have a supervisor signature on the initial treatment plan; R 400.4156
Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care institutions; updated
treatment plan Two of three cases reviewed did not have the signature of the
social service worker on the updated treatment plan and one of three cases
reviewed did not have the signature of the supervisor on the updated treatment
plan.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000729 with CAP approval date of 07/30/2025
was a result of violations of R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio due to the agency’s
failure to document variable interval checks when youth were outside direct
supervision of staff and R 400.4142 Health services due to the agency not
complying with dispensing medication to youth as prescribed. The agency has
submitted an acceptable corrective action plan and is working toward compliance.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000953 is pending a CAP. The CAP is the result
of a violation of R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio due to the agency’s failure to
staff at the ratio consistent with agency policy.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0001013 is pending a CAP. The CAP is the result
of violations of R 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints due to the agency's
failure to complete the proper team control restraint technique, and R 400.4158
Intervention standards and prohibitions due to a supervisor pushing a youth.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns noted after review of Universal Health Services
2024 annual report.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was received and reviewed on 09/05/2025.
Assessment discusses the areas of non-compliance and systemic factors
impacting rule compliance during the last report period. Havenwyck management
continues to work toward addressing staffing shortages and enhancing treatment
for youth in the program. The agency is working collectively to implement action
steps listed in active corrective action plans.
Staff and Youth Interviews

Havenwyck staff were interviewed during the onsite meeting. Staff expressed
concerns regarding staffing shortages, however shared that they believed that the
agency continues to make appropriate attempts to address the matter. No
additional concerns were noted or expressed.
A total of three youth were interviewed during the interim audit. The youth spoke
positively about the agency staff and overall programing. Some youth did report
that the agency is often struggling with staffing which results in a lack of ratio
compliance. Overall, the youth reported feeling safe and nurtured at the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency was completed on 9/4/2025, 9/5/2025 and
9/12/2025. No areas of concern were noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
